in all honesty the idea of saving the honey bee being critical for survival is a bit of a mistake... the use of and expansion of using the European honey bee is part of the reason we are in the situation, humans have put to much into a single species when there are multitudes of pollinators in the natural world. the honey bee is highly efficient and does not only focus on one type of crop to pollinate but pulls nectar from all surrounding flowers thus leaving little to no food for local pollinators to survive on. having a limited genetic pool to work off of is also an issue as it leaves them open to disease and infestation  of mites... reduce reliance on the honey bee and let the local pollinators adapt and come back.

The Burden That Bees Hold:

As a child, I was terrified of bees, I always thought that they would just sting for no reason. As I got older, It is now obvious to me that this isn’t true. Bees sting in self defense, and in doing so, often kill themselves. Recently, there has been so much buzz around the mass death of them. But many of us don’t know why. Colony Collapse Disorder [CCD] is the destruction of bee colonies, through the bee workers abandoning bee hives and queens. This loss in bees is affecting agriculture, and the ecosystem. There are many culprits to this issue but we must find a solution quick. The truth is that we need bees, and we must protect and help them.

Bees experience physical stress and sickness just like humans. Humans have dealt with and are currently dealing with illnesses. Bees are no different. The pollution that we produce is affecting bees as well. The list of suspects has “...included viruses, such as the Israeli acute paralysis virus (IAPV); parasites, such as Varroa mites; insecticides; and even radiation-emitting cell phones” (K. Poltorak). Things that harm us, harm bees and vice versa. Since bees experience physical pain like all living creatures, that means that if bees suffer, we will be soon to follow next. When researchers examined the bees in polluted areas, “[t]heir exoskeletons were covered with particles of pollution… it was rich in heavy metal pollutants such as arsenic and lead, which are as toxic for insects as they are for humans” (A. Hitchings). The exoskeletons of bees were more roughed and damaged compared to samples from non-polluted zones. This could be one of the causes for abnormal bee death, which is what leads to lower populations in Bee hives. Therefore, contributing to CCD. We must establish methods of stopping or reversing these harmful conditions affecting bees. By protecting bees, we are protecting ourselves. Our food and resources are all dependent on bees, and without them, chaos would ensue.

Agricultural crops are killing bees. The human made pesticides that lurk in between the crop foliage is a major culprit. Humans are constantly spraying all kinds of chemicals on produce to keep them from being eaten by insects and pests. One of these being a branch of insecticide known as the Neonicotinoids. This pesticide kills harmful insects but along with it go all insects, including the good ones like bees. Through many studies, “[t]he researchers came to the conclusion that the bees… prefer neonicotinoid-laced solutions… because the chemicals act on the bees' brains… even when consuming the chemicals means the bees are more likely to die” (L. Rieder). So this chemical not only kills bees, but also has an addiction principle added to it. Whenever bees go to pollinate our crops, we have these pesticides waiting for them. When they absorb these chemicals, they won’t just do so and leave. They are likely to come back to these insecticides again raising their chances of death even more. This deadly cycle dwindles bee populations even more, increasing the spread of Colony Collapse Disorder. Without a form of pollination, these plants will suffer. If it kills bees, then without bee pollination, crop amounts will go down drastically, harming ourselves in the long run.


Bees are integrated into multiple ecosystems. Without bees, other species would struggle to survive. Different animals rely on certain plants for food, and humans are no exception. We rely on them to “pollinate 90 fruit, vegetable, spice, and nut crops. Apples, almonds, and allspice… ” (A. Hitchings). These are just to name the plants that humans have a common use for. Many of these plants and herbs are used to not only sustain our farm animals but wild animals as well. This goes up the food chain. For example, if deer eat blackberries and suddenly the quantity of berries goes down, then there will be less deer. If wolves primarily hunt deer, then there will be less deer for them to hunt, and the wolves will struggle as well. If bees stop pollinating even a group of herbs, then the effect will spread up all the way to the apex predator. Stopping CCD becomes a must to help save the environment, and ourselves from extinction.

When I was a child, I visited a farm as a school field trip. That day I visited many bee hives and learned so much about bees. I saw all the farm animals and learned that these animals depend on the bees. From that day I overcame my fear of bees and learned to appreciate them. Bees do not only make honey. They pollinate crops for all the fruits and veggies we eat. Even farm animals eat part of those crops to produce the meat that many of us consume. We owe it to save them. To help bees and the environment, you can take simple steps. Do not litter, waste of any kind, is harmful. Instead of taking a car for close distance travel, walk there, or go on a bike ride for change. Also buying locally grown foods directly supports bees. Foods exported from a distance create more vehicle pollution, which can sicken and kill bees. Bees hold so much weight on their tiny little wings. If bees go, many species including humans will be soon to follow.

How come people swoon over honeybees but then would rather burn a wasp? Like, I hate to break it to people but, and this is for Americans especially, honeybees ain’t as important as wasps.
All the work a bee does? It’d be for naught if it weren’t for the organized murder wasps and hornets commit upon pest insects such as aphids, caterpillars, and for larger species of wasp even things like cicadas are on the menu, like how honeybees are mainly very good at pollinating due to their large hives, vespid hymenopterans are good at insectivory and even scavenging because they can hunt a large amount of prey over a large amount of land at once. This isn’t even going into how wasps also dabble in the pollination business as well by drinking nectar and, indeed, getting covered with pollen.
The main reason I’ve singled out American protection of honeybees is because of one simple fact:
They don’t belong here, straight up
And before you say “well they haven’t hurt the ecosystem in any way” they very much have, they outcompete native species for nesting space (which is considered a factor in the demise of the Carolina parakeet even) and their hives practically breed insect diseases, which honeybees leave all over whatever they pollinate for the next sucker to pick up and die from. Most native plants do not even like honeybee pollination and the pollinators they did rely on such as bumblebees and carpenter bees are in decline, though other factors are involved the sudden widespread hymenopteran diseases are definitely a part of it. In fact, when people first said “save the bees” they hadn’t even meant honeybees! Saving the bees was supposed to be directed at the many endangered solitary bees! Many of which are dying out due to competition from honeybees themselves! While Europe is less so to blame for liking honeybees due to the fact they really are native to there, the native wasps in Europe are also still important for keeping pest populations at acceptable levels.
Not to very much mention the recent murder hornet craze in America is also a reason to blame people because the reason very much boils down to people wanting something to let frustration out on + pre-existing wasp hate with a dash of honeybee-biased “save the bees” as well. Unfortunately the actual murder hornets within North America hadn’t even reached the East coast and people were already smashing any large insect that didn’t even look like a hornet.

In short, while honeybees disappearing may very much be a large issue considering the reliance on honeybee crops, the threat to them is a little over-hyped and their presence in North America is detrimental to the ecosystem outside of captive hives. (which a lot of honeybee hives indeed are outside of captivity.)

Bees have long since provided us with honey, and as hunters became gatherers, pollinated the crops of the world. they still do this today, and we should be grateful for this. Bees pollinate the food we eat, and because they do this labor, 1 out of every 3 bites you take is because of bees and other pollinators. one pesticide is neonicotinoids which is a toxic pesticide that has many bad effects on the human body, including transmitting cancer, splitting apart DNA and chromosomes, and weakening the immune system. This is why these pesticides are dangerous and should be banned. Along with harming the body, it also has bad effects on the environment, by getting into drinking water and killing pollinators. Pesticide is one of the major factors of CCD (colony collapse disorder) which is the mysterious disappearance of bees. this is my point, being bees are crucial to human society, in the way they give us food. The neonicotinoid pesticide that I mentioned earlier has been proven to have no true agricultural effects on soy and scientist believe the same goes for corn, which just shows that money and human health is wasted on practices that could easily be accomplished by cover-cropping and such organic growing methods.

Ahhh...this reminds me when I was 10, I was holding a bunch of flowers, walking around the neighborhood to get more, until I saw people step on a Bumble Bee, and I quickly stopped them. It's wing was chipped, and I crouched down, setting the flowers in front of the bee. The bee, thank goodness, survived, and climbed on the flowers. Slowly getting up, I put my hand near the bee to make sure it didn't fall. And I walked across the street slowly, and I rushed to the other side when I heard a car beep at me. when I got to the other side, the bee was buzzing, and I slowed down. When I got to a playground, I went to a nearby hill, slowly getting down to sit on the sidewalk. While I was doing all that, the bee was pollenating the flowers. Anyway, the bee flew of the flowers, landing on the ground to wipe the pollen off it's face. After that, I watched it fly away, back to the safety of it's hive.

I will never forget that time, but I will always forget what age I was.
My brain decides what I should and should not remember

(Edit): In case you are wondering, this is a true story

Honey Bees are an invasive species brought to America and Asia by European colonialist. They are dying out because they have not adapted to a big majority of the regions in which they were brought. They also kill native pollinator species that are immune to much of the diseases or parasites that they themselves are susceptible to due to them not having adapted to places where those parasites exist. It was because of people, but not recently, it was a problem started by us hundreds of years ago.

Imagine not knowing that only commercial hives are having problems, and being unaware that native pollinators and undomesticated honey bees show no sign of population decline whatsoever. Must be terrifying to live in such fearful ignorance.

The truth is, commercial honey operations use methods that are stressful on bees, and make them more vulnerable to all the things described here. Left to their own devices, or cared for with less-invasive methods, bees do just fine.

Funny that DDT gets mentioned here, since it was only replaced with something allegedly worse based on fraudulent science from environmental activists causing hysteria over another extinction hoax. Rachel Carson's book that led to the DDT ban has been completely debunked, and even science at the time refuted all of her outlandish apocalyptic claims.

DDT saved half a billion lives from malaria in just a couple decades of use. It was safe for humans and the environment, but environmental hysteria forced development of alternatives, which the same environmentalists are now claiming, falsely, will lead to another mass extinction event, and put hundreds of millions of lives at risk from disease and starvation. Fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice, shame on me. Environmentalists will not be happy until humans are extinct, or at least living in the stone age and at much lower population numbers.

Signed,
An Actual Beekeeper

P.S. I'm no fan of commercial monoculture farming, and I actually own and run what you'd probably call an organic farm (although the label is meaningless and I don't use it myself nor does any farmer I respect). There's plenty to criticize about modern agriculture practices. Using fearmongering and lies to push your agenda doesn't help anyone, though, and it completely destroys your credibility. People become numb to your apocalyptic predictions after you've cried wolf enough times.

I like to lead by example, to develop and demonstrate actual viable alternatives that prove you can feed the world with some clever human planning and ecologically-sound practices. Ultimately it is the free market that will achieve the sort of ecological balance environmentalists claim to want to have, and do so without forcing humans to die off themselves, or to accept primitive living standards. I make a very nice income without the use of artificial pesticides, and feed a lot of people very good healthy food with my land. What it takes is some careful planning, human brainpower, and quite frankly a minimum of government intervention so I have the ability to experiment freely. When you start mandating things, however noble your intentions, you destroy the creative process that allows for better solutions to come along. If you want to know more, read Joel Salatin's book "Everything I Want to Do Is Illegal".

2 major factors this video has left out are... that African Honey bees have a very high degree of resistance & immuntity to the parasites, viruses, & fungi that infect European Honey bees.
They are largely immune to the viruses, fungi, & internal parasites... & very resistant to external parasites, because African Honey bees are voracious groomers.

The 2nd thing is... African Honey bees are more resistant to Neonicotinoids than European Honey bees.
The studies companies use to promote their use, rather than find an alternative....are based on the limited effects they have on African bees... while independent researchers focused their studies on the effects on European bees, because 99% of our crops are pollinated by European Honey bees, & because bee keepers don't keep African Honey bees.

This video is absolute garbage. We know EXACTLY why bees are dying out and, sorry, it's not really a big problem. In fact, there are NO native honey bees in the United States... at all. We imported them all from Europe and we use them as a commercial tool. They are NOT a part of the natural ecosystem (at least in the US).

As far as the exact problems, the commercial bees are largely dying out because they keep stealing all the honey and replacing the majority of it with an artificial sugar mush mess which lacks certain natural goodies, the most important being p-coumaric acid which activates specific genes which boost the bee's natural immune system... and without it they become exponentially more susceptible to pesticides and disease.

Wild bees on the flip side have OTHER problems, largely due to human expansion and roadways. Basically wiping out wildflowers and building new roads... bees go SQUISH on people's windshields.

A plant-based diet is the most sustainable diet as it uses less water, crops, land, and produces the fewest greenhouse gases. This video represents what I believe is everyone’s basic understanding of the problems facing honey bees today. But it is missing some facts... big facts. The poor, sad, dying honey bee that we are hearing so much about lately is only one of 16,000 bee species, and it is not even native to North America. It’s a good thing that we are looking out for these little critters, but why are we only worried about the honey bees and ignoring the other 16,000 species? I just want to say why I don't agree with this because, why not? Honeybees aren't native to America. They are an invasive species that were smuggled (if that's the right term) into America in 1622, not because of their ability to pollinate, but their ability to make honey. This means that nature is more than capable of stabilizing and even flourishing without bees. Also there are already organisms to pollinate plants for people. It's just sometimes, you won't see too many of them because they crowd out all the other local pollinators. They even kill them by spilling pathogens on them. So in conclusion, we don't really need bees. Bonus argument: I didn't use this because this usually happens due to people being foolish. Also some people are allergic to bees. Also, while in some areas honey bees have taken over the niches of wild solitary bees, there are also examples of harmonious coexistence - in Panama for example both some of the local orchid bees and Africanized honey bees pollinate the same flowers, but instead of this having led to competition it has resulted in the local flora reproducing more than ever and in population increases for both wild and honey bees! (All of this is in a curiosity stream documentary called "Secrets of the hive")
Bottom line is honey bees do a lot more good to the environment and human civilization than they do bad, so even if you dislike them you should grow up and support saving them!
Take care of your bees guys :)

European bees are not indigenous to not Europe. "Killer bee's" or africanized bees though more aggressive and engineered are indigenous to the American continent. Africanized bees produce more robust yields of honey, but they don't domesticate as easily, which might explain why European bees are still relied on to pollinate american crops

Honey bees aren't the only pollinators. In America, they're an invasive species.

Farmers need to import paper wasps. Smaller colonies mean less disease spread. Their shells are more resistant to mites, and the lack of hair makes them unappealing to mites. They are slightly less efficient than bees at pollinating, but they eat a lot more nectar, which makes up for that. The best part, however, is that wasps can solve a few of the problems affecting bees. Their larvae don't eat honey. Instead, adult wasps capture and kill several bugs to feed larvae, including aphids, caterpillars, and other garden pests; as well as mosquitos, certain mites and othe parasites. They increase the available nectar, and they decrease the number of parasites and the need for pesticides that kill bees. And paper wasps are chill and prefer to keep to themselves. Unlike bees, wasps don't form huge armies. They're pretty relaxed, and only one or two workers go out at a time. This means that they are unlikely to fight with bees. They're like ladybugs, but more efficient, more versatile, and more useful.

Okay let me give you some information about pollen grains and pollination. Most of you must know this thing. First of all pollination is a process by which pollen grains from another of a flower is attached to stigma of another or the same flower by the action of air or animals. The whole process of pollination and reproduction of flower ~

The anther of a flower contains tiny particals called pollen grains inside them. When these pollen grains come out of anther, these pollen grains stick to stigma of the same plant or another plant by the action of air or animal. Let's take an example of bees. Bees sit of flower to suck nectar. At this time, the pollen grains stick to their legs and fall into another flower's stigma or the same one. The pollen grains make a narrow pasage through style to reach the ovule which is present inside ovary. The ovule and pollen grains together form zygote. The ovule becomes the seed and the ovary becomes the fruit. This is the whole process of reproduction and pollination. Thank you for reading this...... I hope this helps you......😄😄😄

There's another scientifically-backed video explaining why honey bees in the Americas SHOULD die.  Before they were introduced into the North American ecosystems there were already bees, different bees, doing all the pollination that nature required.  Now that Honey Bees are around and getting preferential treatment from humans and a lack of predators, the natural pollinators of North America are having a hard time.  If there were fewer Honey Bees, the other species would pick up the slack, no dead crops.  I do think however, that Honey Bee issues could be a big problem in Europe, where they originally evolved. Writing my speech on saving bees

Monsanto GMOs are another factor, partially as a result of Monsanto and Bayer's political maneuvering to dismantle the IPM, to make their crops the only real option. Monsanto's GMO seeds have five times the neonicotinoids normally acquired by spraying, built right into them. They were, of course, tested safe for bees, but the research was not long term enough to discover that the honey made from these crops, while not sufficiently poisonous to kill the bees directly, sterilized drones.

The majority of colony collapses in the US observe a pattern, not where the hive is slowly weakened by neonicotinoids and parasites, but instead where there is a sudden collapse, caused by a lack of fertile drones, leading to the absence of a fertilized queen.

While GMOs, even under the current population levels, are a requirement for continued human survival, allowing the patenting of genes leads to crooked business practice such as this, where the companies have a profit motive to dismantle regulatory bodies, risking catastrophic environmental damage and the integrity of the food supply itself. If gene patenting were illegal, the only research profit motive remaining would be the desire to increase crop yields, and since only the agricultural industry itself would fund that, it'd be much more hesitant to prematurely apply changes to its own product that may, in the long run, destroy it. Unlike Monsanto, which does not rely directly on the product they are altering, they couldn't take the money and run in case of such disasters. (Plus, going to your CRISPR video, you'd have the added benefit that you wouldn't run the risk of generations of patented humans.)

On the other hand, there is an obvious solution to all this: GMO your bees.

I live in Barrie Ontario Canada.In the past few years I noticed a decline of assorted bees and wasps . Normally there would be 150 to 200 bees/wasps in the perennial garden /annual flowers and veggie garden . That declined in 2014 to 2016 to about 25 bees/wasps .But this year 2017 I have seen a huge comeback of bees/wasps in my garden .Back to normal levels of 150 to 200 bees (honey and bumble bees/wasps happily pollinating and gathering nectar. I realize there are studies on the use of pesticides ,fungicides and bee parasites. I don't use any pesticides and use limited organic fertilizers. I prefer using compost ,eggshells and coffee grounds ,epsom salts as fertilizers . All I know is that the bees/wasps have dramatically increased in my garden back to 150 to 200 .

This is the most disappointing Kurzgesagt episode to date.  Full of inaccuracies and shortcuts.  The bottom line is this: there is 25,000 bee species in the world, disappearing of one of them doesn't mean the end of days.  Especially in continents outside of honeybees natural range (Europe and North Africa).  North American continent with it's own 4,500 bee species was doing just fine before Europeans brought their honeybees.  Honeybees are not even that good pollinators (compared to native and solitary bees).  They can't for example pollinate tomatoes (which were listed as one of the things that would disappear without them).  In many places of the world European honeybee is an exotic and invasive species, their importance to humans doesn't change the fact that they can wreck environmental havoc on native species (out competing them for food, spreading disease etc.).  Shortly: honeybee and bee are not interchangeable terms and we will do just fine without the European honeybee, especially in places they were never present in the first place.

So, what can we do about this in our gardens and farms?

Are bee colonies dying ? Yes. Does that mean the number of bee colonies has decreased? No, there are actually more bee colonies now than when the colony collapse disorder began. (Source: https://d1jn4vzj53eli5.cloudfront.net/mc/bburch/2017_08/beechart.jpg?h=286&w=400) You might be wondering why this is the case, but its actually pretty simple: Beekeepers have plenty of strategies to replace lost colonies. If they loose half of there colonies, they just replace them with new ones. And this is pretty easy, things like splitting a hive can accomplish it, somethings they have to buy packaged bees. But they are so good at it, that it hardly affects pollination fees and honey prices. Also the EU's partial ban on neonicotinoids in 2013 has done more harm than good, by encouraging farmers to use other, more lethal pesticides.

Honey bees are not native to North America and have been displacing the native pollinators. They were introduced by European settlers. While we could survive the loss of honey bees in North America, it would indeed lead to dramatic changes in agriculture, because we have built agriculture around so many imported species that rely on the honey bee. Everywhere we go, we change the environment. Eventually the changes come back to haunt us. The use and abuse of honey bees is probably just one example of many.

Hello! I'm a vet specialized in ticks and mites and recently I've done some work on Varroa and honeybees.

Just throwing the fact out here in case anyone's interested - right now honey beekeepers are losing about 40% of their honey production every year due to Varroa and it has a terrible effect on the hive's size, but it's not enough to explain colony collapse syndrome. The same goes for insecticides since bees that are kept in insecticide-free environments are also being affected by this problem.

The things pointed out in this video are correct and highly jarring to hives, but currently, we don't know what exactly causes Colony Collapse Syndrome, and it's speculated that it's something other than those things.

So, here's the thing. Talking about neonics and pesticides with respect to CCD is really opening a can of worms. Any sane person can probably reach the relatively safe conclusion that pesticides in general are not healthy for bees, and neonics are certainly no exception to that general maxim, but reaching any conclusion more specific than the vague notion that they apply some amount of negative pressure to bee populations is dangerous. Unfortunately, this is a subject that has been infected with bad science from one very specific and particular individual - Chengsheng Lu of Harvard University. Without getting too far into the weeds, suffice it to say that Lu is a dedicated ideologue who has spent his entire career carrying out motivated, activist science (and those two words are bad when you put them together - science needs to be conducted from a point of objectivity - "what is happening that explains this observation?" - and not from one of advocacy - "this observation is clear evidence that XXXX is happening!") in some sort of bizarre personal jihad against non-organic pesticides. He's a crank with a megaphone and his insistence on charging out to the front of the crowd and cheerleading this particular subject is damaging in basically every conceivable way.

The complicating factor here is that pesticides are necessary, full stop. Without pesticides, we can't have agriculture on the scale that we need to feed people. It's just not possible. The question we have to at least try to answer is how far we can relax our pesticide usage - a discussion that Lu is not helping, and neither is the alarmism in this video. Bees are insects, insects are pests, and agriculture on a scale capable of feeding seven billion people requires the elimination of pests. Bees WILL get caught in the crossfire to some extent. Changing from neonics to something else is not terribly likely to help them in the long term - whatever substance we settle on will still be deleterious to bees to some extent. Let's not pretend that the rise of neonics in the market is the result of some shadowy conspiracy of a bunch of weirdos in suits who just hate bees - they're used as widely as they are because they're cheap and effective.

Un/Fortunately, CCD is almost certainly not A thing. That's not the way that extinction pressure seems to work in nature, so far as we are able to observe. Parasites certainly play a substantial role and there's little reason to believe that we would lose anything by destroying them, so fighting those should probably be first on the agenda. Finding an alternative pesticide that's less deleterious to bees (or making the bees less vulnerable to the pesticide) is another area where there's stuff we can do. Most likely we're going to have to do all of those things to make any sort of a difference.

Funny how money and productivity are brought into the discussion, because productivity and money are actually the reasons behind the loss of the bees. The pesticides, economic zoning and monocular were meant to increase productivity, and I'm sure they did for a while, however this leads to highly increased concentrations of pesticides in these zones, which then leads to what is becoming dead zones. Funny enough the quest for maximum productivity will soon produce no food at all.

People need to stop worshiping money, we do not need it as much as we need food, and for that we need bees. Bees>Money.

The modern systems are wrong on so many lvls, what we really need to return to is the style of sporadically placed farms found in "under developed" countries due to no economic regions at all, however in lieu of that, we could possibly go to the organic style of pesticide free farming found in France and Russia, where the bumble bees are common, and the earth yields more per acre than the poisoned ground of the US.

I believe the parasites are a bit of a red herring, the theory I find most credible is the one where the bees who go out to get the nectar for the honey are killed before they return, lesser number do return, but do not keep up with the hive production, so a larger number of embryos will die do to disease because that stage of the hive will be very slow in production, leaving the embryos exposed to parasites for much longer periods of time. With an ever diminishing number of workers collecting nectar, inevitable it spells the end of the hive.

The whole GMO, Monsanto business model is going to wipe most of us out if we let it persist. Since I get no economic gains from their existence, I hope very much they go away very very quickly. The poison on much of the earths farmland is now due to their poisons unable to grow any other plants, and the yields of the existing plants is diminishing. How deep does the poison go now? We might be able to dig it up, turn the soil and start planting normal again, but for how long ? Time is of the essence.

Some research has also indicated that honey bees can compete for resources with e.g. solitary bees, which indicates that the loss of functions provided by honey bee populations could be compensated by increasing resource availability for wild bees and other pollinating insects. oh boy. for the first time, I know about a thing enough to argue on a kurzgesagt video.
Some of this is wrong. Honeybees are a big business in the USA but they're also invasive to North America. Their existence threatens the existence of native pollinators and even of native plant species.
"one out of three meals eaten by humans is made possible by honeybees"
that's frankly false. One out of every three meals eaten by humans is made possible by POLLINATORS but honeybees are not the only pollinator and are in fact unable to pollinate many plants native to North America. Many native North American plants require buzz pollination which honeybees can't do. Bumblebees can. Bumblebees have less to eat with all these European honeybees going around stealing their food. There are many non-honeybee pollinators includes other bees, wasps, ants, beetles, moths, and even some birds. Furthermore, crop yields are better from human pollination than they are from honeybee pollination.

The reason we all hear all this nonsense about saving honeybees in the US is because it's a fifteen BILLION dollar industry. Companies like Monsanto ship honeybees around the country charging for their services and then harvesting and selling the honey that results. Even liberal estimates put only 15% of honeybees in the US being wild while the rest are owned and shipped around like that.

In conclusion: screw the honeybee (in the US). It's just greedy companies trying to hire bee labor because it's cheaper than human labor and produces honey. Saying "save the honeybee!!!" is like saying "save the zebra mussel!!!"
it's an invasive species and our ecology would be 100% fine if it went extinct within North America.

While this is a serious problem, the corporation/capitalism-fear-mongering isn't necessary. The EPA issued a moratorium on Neonics back in March of 2015, and the Obama Administration established two commissions to help solve the CCD problem. Also, while Neonics are banned in Europe, back in 2013 Spain lost 80% of its colonies.

Meanwhile in Canada, where 80% of the Canola is grown with Neonic use, there was no noticeable difference in bee populations in 2013.

That Harvard study that is cited for the toxicity of Neonics to bees was found to be deeply flawed, and with concentrations far higher than anything found in real world scenarios.

And let's not forget that last year, bee populations reached their highest numbers in 20 years.

So while CCD is a serious problem involving multiple factors and there's no conclusive answer as to why this is happening, alarmism about corporations and chemical pesticides is not honest, and does not represent scientific thinking.

I'm usually impressed with these videos, but this one is very poorly researched and just seems to be feeding into confusion and hype.

Colony collapse is less than 10% of yearly failed hives. The response from the beekeeper community has been to just make more hives. Yes, honeybees are a livestock. Letting them go extinct on accident is like letting sheep go extinct on accident. Probably not going to happen.
The honeybee is being hurt more by cold weather, since they're a tropical insect, and the mite he sort of mentioned (33% of hive failures) than by colony collapse.

And if honeybees do go extinct, which they wont, because WE CONTROL THEIR ENTIRE POPULATION GROWTH, then there will always be the 1000s of species of wild bee to choose from. You know... the ones that pollinate all other plant life.

In the 50's, we took up beekeeping.  A scientist was hired to explain how to be a beekeeper. One, put mustard around the hive hole to keep ants out.  Two, don't put hives near dung or dog, cat poo as dung attracts parasites. How much dung do farmers put on crops near beehives? Three, never, never keep the Queen inside, she has to get out to poo, otherwise, the smell of poo will build up. And, the Queen has 2000 eggs to lay in a day or 1 million in a lifetime, but, problems arise, do they not, when she runs out of space, thus, we were told, the eggs will hatch inside her and eat her from the inside out, if, the heart, kidneys, lungs do not go first as they run out of space.  Male birds hop, fly, and bring gifts to the female when courting. What do the males do in the Queen's presence.  Maybe, they have a ritual no one knows about. This story is riddled with factual errors. The best estimates of the contribution of insects to crop pollination is 6% not 33%. Of this only about 1/3 is due to honeybees which means they contribute about 2%, not 33% to world food production. Also honeybees are not in decline. The most credible recent study shows that honey bees populations are stable. The errors go on and on. This story sounds like someone has taken all the most alarming and false myths on this topic and stitched them together. It is time to introduce evidence into this debate.

Hi guys, we are a small association, IMPACT, which gather students in order
to develop projects related to biology. This year we decided that our projects
should be connected to ecology and the world health. We are currently trying to
create a biosensor, able to detect bees infection by pathogens (which are
partially responsible of colony collapse disorder CCD) that take advantage of
bees deficient immunity system (thanks to the massive use of pesticide), and
would allow beekeepers to have a swift, and directed reaction. But we need

The drop from 4 million hives to 2.5M is a regional figure for the US. If you look globally, the number of hives has grown almost 50% over the last fifty years.

http://www.cell.com/current-biology/abstract/S0960-9822%2809%2900982-8 :
"To date, evidence for a global crisis has been drawn from regional or local declines in pollinators themselves or insufficient pollination for particular crops. In contrast, our analysis of Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) data reveals that the global population of managed honey-bee hives has increased ∼45% during the last half century and suggests that economic globalization, rather than biological factors, drives both the dynamics of the global managed honey-bee population and increasing demands for agricultural pollination services"

I cringe every I hear "Honey Bee" in this video. Honey Bees make up a small portion of the total "bee" population. Honey Bee populations are also stabilizing. Beekeepers were the first to notice colony collapse disorder and took action fairly quickly. Wild honey bees do exist but most of them are domesticated.

Bumblebees are REALLY hurting. Bumblebees also feed a wider array of plants. They are also active for much longer periods than honey bees. And while there is only 1 or 2 species of honey bee depending on where you live in the world,there are dozens of bumblebee species. That's what we need to worry about.

Not denying that bee deaths are a serious problem.  Neonicatanoids represent a group of what is known as systemic insecticides.  This means seeds are treated before they go in the ground and they pesticide spreads through the plant as it grows.  I'm not sure I can agree with how the OP approached this.  Considering corn is not a terribly nutritious pollen source for bees (which they argue is the main cause of bee deaths).  A couple studies have cited that it only makes up about 3.5% of all pollen in bee hives (here:  http://www.researchgate.net/profile/G_Cutler/publication/265418943_A_field_study_examining_the_effects_of_exposure_to_neonicotinoid_seed-treated_corn_on_commercial_bumble_bee_colonies/links/5490eace0cf214269f27d607.pdf)  

Bees do have preference if foraging.  If there is better pollen around that is what they will go for.  

I would seriously hesitate against the ban of neonics, as it would force farmers to resort to far more toxic pesticides in order to protect their crops.  I encourage decisions based on solid, repeatable science.  

Evidence that neonics are the sole source of bee population downfall is not solid, and at times statistically questionable.

A good chunk of the problems are genetically modified crops that are designed to withstand pesticides better, and all the money that's poured into monopolizing food production with that. The pesticides don't kill the crops, and people keep pouring more Round-Up on the crops. It's a huge problem for waste water and diversity of plant life too because the pesticides still kill plants that aren't modified to withstand them. And it's a problem within diversity of crop yields and by building better pests because it encourages farmers to not rotate crops. Note: I'm not saying anything here about crops modified for yield or what not, or taking an automatic anti-GMO stance. I'm talking specifically about excess use of poisons used on food crops.

My father keeps canaries and like many bird keepers had problems with red mite. For many years he had tried keeping them at bay with pesticides.
But the pesticides attack the nervous system of living mites and not of their eggs because those are hidden. You also can't hit them all because you can't find them all. And on top of that mites quickly go through many generations so they can quickly randomly mutate a resistance.

So when I heard him having this problem I introduced a crazy solution. Every animal has a natural predator and in the case of red mite it's the phytoseiulus persimilis which you can easily order thanks to the crazy world web web.
So instead of losing an expensive and labor intensive fight, he sets out a few containers of phytoseiulus persimilis which takes less than 5 minutes and it's a lot cheaper.
- phytoseiulus persimilis breed faster than red mites and breed with a higher tolerance to environment variables so they outpopulate them fast even if you only set out a few thousand.
- red mites have 0 defense against phytoseiulus persimilis (their heads get ripped off :/).
- phytoseiulus persimilis hunt day and night for both the red mites, their larve and their eggs.
- phytoseiulus persimilis are smaller than red mites and will get to any nook and cranny where they hide.
- phytoseiulus persimilis do nothing against any other animal. It's a mite that evolved to solely survive on other mites.
- when the red mites are gone the phytoseiulus persimilis turn cannibalistic so there's no cleanup.

TLDR: Pesticides are not the easiest or the cheapest or the best way to protect our economy.
PS: Worst of all, the Wikipedia article for red mites advocates using pesticides! It's disgusting.

One tactic that significantly reduces colony loss for commercial bee hives is to store them in a warehouse kept at 40F or about 2 to 5 C in the winter.

Giving bees a rest instead of just moving them further south can help tremendously.

Another thing that can be done is breed tougher bees.

As well as improving their nutrition with sugary water. Particularly for bees whose honey is harvested for human consumption.

But of course we need more than bee keepers on board.

This is a disappointingly biased video. The phenomenon of CCD is complex, and is a newer name for events like it that have been recorded since the 19th century. Additionally, it has not continued to cause major overall declines in colonies as asserted, as hive numbers have remained steady or even increased in the past decade; let alone the utterly skewed "30-90%" loss (which leaves out the fact that those numbers are winter losses, which always happen to some degree, and usually recover in spring).
In fact, most of the high losses are in the mobile hives that travel thousands of km every year, and probably stress out the hives just by that activity.
Then there is the finality of the assertion of lethalness of neonicotinoids, which is based on a few studies with extremely poor methodologies (such as overly long feeding periods, or orders of magnitude higher concentrations). In fact, researchers like Chensheng Lu have made it clear that they are out to prove that neonics are bad, rather than actually objectively testing it.
And your cartoons are pure disinformation (apart from the very emotional skulls), as neonics are never sprayed onto a field, but applied to the seeds before sowing.

This video is a lot of fear mongering that this channel is usually above. First off, the 5 million in 1988 number, to 2.5 million today? Is a gross characterization of CCD and how it has affected populations. It fails to mention that the mites arrived (Or flourished) in NA in 1990 according the USDA, they weren't a pest the bees always had to deal with .

http://www.ars.usda.gov/News/docs.htm?docid=15572#losses

By the time the first cases of CCD were being reported, in 2006? The population of hives was already down to 2.7 million. The vast bulk of the decline was due to mites well before CCD. Every year the 33% die off rate, only around 1/3 is attributed to CCD. And it's hardly an open and shut case as to why this happens...(Which means CCD probably accounted for WAY LESS of the die off than the mite losses did, which spiked in 04, before CCD was a thing).

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jon-entine/post_8761_b_6323626.html

Plenty of research, NOT funded by the chemical companies, pokes holes in blaming it on pesticides. The fact is, globally, bees are still on the rise; the presence of CCD in the U.S. and the EU could actually be because a combination of the new mite, with us using bees more thanks to a larger crop industry (Adding stress to their environment) combined with the extra viral and bacterial agents introduced by the new mite.

I'm actually really surprised you glossed over the mite as "something they could handle!" Listen, in the end, I don't know if the pesticides are contributing the CCD--what I do know is 1.) This isn't as dire as it sounds, population levels have been increasing slowly for the last decade. Yes it's a problem, but life as we know it is not in danger any time soon, the EPA and other environmental agencies are conducting long term studies for a reason, we shouldn't panic and make dumb choices. 2.) This video really attempts to pin point the problem, when in fact no one really knows yet. And this isn't some global warming denliasm or something--many scientists and even environmental agencies are hotly debating this (But I did like the intimation that anyone who disagrees is an agent of the evil chemical companies--you know, because it's not a rational concern that the lab tests which "prove" the pesticide is a problem required the bees to be freaking doused with it, while in a field setting the PPM they'd be exposed to would be MUCH MUCH lower. Nooo, you'd have to work for those companies to think that--lol)

Politics and sensationalism in a complex issue like this can be...bad. For example, Europe is still having CCD happen, despite banning the product in question. And this year they are looking at 20% lower yields on crops, which can have a disastrous effect on humans--despite the fact that their bee populations had been level for a freaking decade before deciding to ban this substance. (IE illustrating this was a political, not rational choice.)

Some of your information is a bit dated.  Last year a couple studies were published that severely questions the link between neonics and ccd.  Also, at least in the US, CCD reemerged in about 2004, by 2008 colonies hit an all time low, but since then colony numbers have been growing fairly steadily.  Also note that CCD type events have occurred in waves and been recorded for a couple centuries now, with no explanation ever found, outside of heightened mite activity being a likely contributor.  We still need to investigate causes and find ways to protect current colonies as well as foster new ones, but most evidence is that colonies are currently getting stronger and numbers are firmly rising.  Again, This is in the US, I don't know global numbers, and we may be unusual.

A terrible amount of "perhaps, maybe, and probably" for a video sponsored by an academy of sciences :/ ...the reality is that at the moment, all we can do is point fingers. There really is no definitive cause behind this phenomenon.

On the subject of neonicitinoids I may have found a theoretical solution. Since the action of this class of pesticide is to over stimulate the acetylcholine receptors could this action be reversed with acetylcholine antagonists?
Take datura stramonium for instance, it biosynthesizes tropane alkaloids like scopolamine and hyscosamine. These naturally occuring drugs could counteract the action of neonicitinoids.
I would go a step further to say that if a bee keeper were to grow these types of plants near the hive that the pollen and nectar collected by the bees could give them immunity to the pesticides. The honey created by the bees could also hold the medicinal benefits of tropane alkaloids as well.
This is mere speculation but from what I know of neurochemistry this could be a solution to one of the threats for the Honey Bee.

If there's one thing I can agree on, it's this problem.  And I can agree that humans cause it.

I'm a big bug fan.  I love insects, have since I was a kid.  One of my most cherished memories and a favorite campfire story is when I was little and my dad had to shout at me several times to get me running because my younger brother stirred up a ground wasp's nest.  Insects are the most important part of our world and without them things would be very different, and not for the better.  They also happen to be the world's greatest survivors, having endured several mass extinctions.

One day I noticed that there were fewer dandelion plants growing in our yard.  It makes sense because they're considered weeds, but I always found flowering plants in lawns to be a positive thing...except suddenly they weren't there anymore.  Then it occurred to me; there were less bees the years before, only wasps.  Was it because they moved the apiaries? Or was it something else?

We used insecticides on a daily basis in order to protect crops.  A large portion of those crops aren't even used for food; they are used for 'ethanol' which is to help lower the financial problems regarding the so-called 'oil crisis' that has been going on.  But those pesticides have had a lot of negative problems to our environment.  With DDT, all we had to do was shout, "Our national symbol's gonna die" and that got rid of the problem fast.  But what about the bees?

Paul Stamets outlines the best method of preventing and reversing colony collapse disorder using mushrooms and myco-honey (a mycelium derivitive).  The disappearance of "Old Growth Forest" and the eradication of our fugi ecosystems is what allowed the problems facing the bee to grow unchecked for so long.  Worker bees feed on mycelium (Mushroom root structure) and that food they ingest serves to help them resist mites and purify their bodies of toxins introduced as pesticides.  With so little mushroom mycelium availible they mites and pesticides are now overpowering the bees.  Worker bees die off sooner so brood bees are prematurely promoted to replace them leaving the hive uncared for which leads to Colony Collapse.

It isn't trivial to say that there is a conspiracy to keep neonicotinoids legal.  Are you sure that neonics are to blame, or have you just heard that?  
I like most of your videos, but you tend towards corporate conspiracy theories too often.  Neonics MAY be the cause, but I doubt that there is a conspiracy keeping it legal.  it seems to be a lack of evidence and a lack of a safer alternative.  It also seems that CCD is still occurring in places that do not use Neonics anyway.
The difference in opinion between experts and laymen on this seems important to me. Most bee ecologists I have read seem to doubt the claim that neonics are to blame. More often than not they will say that it MAY be a contributing FACTOR, not that it is the cause.
Perhaps it would be wise to not comment on something so complicated if you aren't a bee ecologist or are not equipped to critically review all of the data on this.  I understand the importance of informing people and compelling them to take action, but if you are wrong you are needlessly burdening the regulatory systems and further discrediting any serious environmental protection movement.
It is like crying wolf.  Every time the public gets outraged about something based on little information and the public is wrong, people have good reason to doubt environmental movements in general.  Do you think climate change denial would be possible if it weren't for environmental activists having been demonstrably wrong so often in the past?
Before you comment, here are a few points I have to make to avoid the predictable:
1. I don't claim to know one way or another about the neonics and CCD.  I just think it is important to not be wrong about this.  
2. I do not work for any company that manufactures pesticides (which is exactly what a paid shill would say, but I don't care to argue with crazy people so fuck off if that is where your mind immediately goes when someone challenges your opinion.).
3. I DO care about the environment and I am not advocating a blind trust in authority.
4. I would be behind the banning of Neonics in a heart beat if I weren't so concerned that this "giant" in the distance isn't just a "windmill" (see Don Quixote).
5. An article written by a journalist isn't evidence. 
6. Individual studies are not "proof".
7.  I am fully aware that there are a LOT of beekeepers who blame neonics, but you don't have to be a biologist/ecologist to be a beekeeper.
If you care about nature, the nature cares about you.

Solutions:
-Stop buying manmade honeycomb if it's not matched to local bee-sizes. Beekeepers use manmade honeycomb as a foundation for their honey bee hives. The honeycomb pattern is too big for the bees. A bigger cell produces a bigger bee. If a bee grows up in a larger cell, it's trachea and thorax are larger. If it's trachea is too big, acarpis becomes a problem. If it's thorax is too big, female egg-laying varroa mites have an opportunity to hide between the wings where the bee can't shake them off. Bees are smart enough to shake varroa off outside the hive, but they can't if the bee is too big. Also, when the cell is too big, varroa mites thrive off of excess body mass the bee-larva develops because of the excess food in it's surroundings as it grows. To add insult to injury, there are many insecticides used in beekeeping that have insecticide contaminated the wax. Never buy wax from countries where these insecticides are still legal. (USA) And especially don't use manmade foundatation honeycomb made from it.
-Stop buying package bees and queens from overseas. Instead, breed your own queens. Beekeepers buy queens from overseas instead of raising their own. These queens are usually inbred because breeders tend to cull queens. It also means that the bees may not survive a winter in the new climate. They aren't bred to be good at adapting to new climates, they're bred for honey production local to the place where they were bred.
-Stop using queen excluders. Beekeepers use what's called a "Queen Excluder" in their hives. When honeybees climb through these, their wings get shredded up over time. A bee  with prematurely shredded wings prematurely dies.
-Let them have flowers. It's a food desert out there. Many farmers mow around their fields without consideration for the bees. Sometimes farming communities mow everything at the same time. That's bad too. Bees need the nectar from the wildflowers in the ditches and fields, so don't mow them.
-Give them mycelium. There are fewer and fewer sources of mycelium available to bees because of deforestation and our need for lumber. Mycelium is health food for bees. It boosts their immune systems and is a preventative for viral infections and chemical contamination. If you lived off of just veggies and no fungi or meat, you'd be lethargic too. Bees need edible mushrooms and mycelium in their diets like they have in nature.
-Stop using neonics. This one's obvious.
-Stop relying on insecticides (used in beekeeping as medicine) to temporarily solve problems.

This study from 2013 concluded that neonicotinoids are harming bees and safer alternatives are needed: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1877343513000493

This report from 2015 has similar conclusions: http://www.easac.eu/fileadmin/Reports/Easac_15_ES_web_complete.pdf

I'm not finding evidence to suggest that the reaction against neonicotinoid is a conspiracy theory; this one has actual papers. This is more like "AGW is a thing" (which is a warning science stands behind) than "Vaccines cause autism" (which is not a warning that science stands behind).
